page.title: 03Buildings. Swainby & Potto
page.content: The most dominant buildings are {Swainby}Church, built in 1875-77, and the Victorian Vicarage. The older houses, dating from 1718, are of local freestone, with distinctive kneelers and pantiled gabled roofs. Yorkshire sliding-sash windows were traditional in these buildings. The majority of the old cottages have been modernised and extended but maintaining the vernacular wherever possible. The bungalows for the elderly are terraced single-storied brick units with landscaped open-plan grounds. In {Potto,}the original cottages are of locally made brick. Potto Hall, built in the 1860s as a private house and now a club/hotel, is the main substantial building, standing outside the township. Modern building has been mainly restricted to bungalows, some with dormer windows.
